title: West Shore Docks, Weehawken, New Jersey

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of watercolor with blotting, wiping and scraping, on lightweight, slightly textured, ivory wove paper (top, right and left edges trimmed), laid down on white card.

description: Upon his return to Weekawken in 1910, Marin created a work in which he handled watercolor in the fluid, flooded manner of his Tyrolean landscapes. Like those mountain scenes, this watercolor was constructed in horizontal bands, with an expanse of paper left nearly empty in the middle ground, where the pale stains of wiped, blotted color evoke the dull glare of the river’s surface. This free wet-into-wet application appears in numerous other Weehawken images in which Marin allowed his colors to bleed into each other, giving the scenes of river commerce the soft glow of wintry dawn light. Here Marin’s vantage point high on the riverbank encouraged him to flatten the composition; the shapes of the Weehawken piers extend upward along the picture plane rather than leading the eye into deep space.
medium_display: Watercolor with blotting, wiping and scraping, on lightweight, slightly textured, ivory wove paper (top, right and left edges trimmed), laid down on white card
inscriptions: Signed lower left, in graphite: “Marin”; inscribed verso, center, in graphite: “AS”
publication_history:
Sheldon Reich, John Marin: A Stylistic Analysis and Catalogue Raisonné (Tucson, 1970), p. 357, no. 10.91 (ill.).

Hedy Weiss, "John Marin —Watercolors a vivid world portrait at Art Institute of Chicago" Chicago SunTimes (April 28, 2011), accessed May 2, 2011, http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/3507159-452/story.html (not repro).
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, "John Marin's Watercolors: A Medium for Modernism," Jan. 19-Apr. 17, 2011, pp. 106-107, p. 32; traveled to the High Museum, Atlanta, June 26-Sept. 11, 2011.
provenance_text: Alfred Stieglitz (1864–1946), New York; Stieglitz Estate (Georgia O'Keeffe (1887–1986), executor); given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1956.
copyright_notice: © 2018 Estate of John Marin / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

input: West Shore Docks, Weehawken, New Jersey
